questions.question: There weren't ................................ students in the class.
questions.description: We use many before plural nouns and much before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: He doesn't have ................................. patience.
questions.description: We use much before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: We haven't got ............................. time to prepare for the test.
questions.description: We use much before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I like your parents ............................
questions.description: Much is not normally used with like and dislike in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: I managed to solve the puzzle with .............................. difficulty.
questions.description: We use little before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I got ............................. apples than her.
questions.description: Fewer is the comparative form of few. We use it before a plural noun.

questions.question: I earn ................................. than my sister.
questions.description: In this context, less is the comparative form of little.

questions.question: We experienced far .................................. problems than we were expecting.
The company does not make ............................... money these days.
............................. want a new system.
questions.description: Many is not normally used alone to mean 'many people'.

questions.question: She is extremely close to ................................. friends she has.
questions.description: The few means not many but all that you have.

questions.question: I .............................. enjoyed my stay with your family.
